align*:
\begin{align}                                           \label{evarth}
  \frac1{m^2}\frac{delta S}{delta\Theta}=~~~~
  &-2\square\Theta+2{\sf\,sin\,}\Theta{\sf\,cos\,}\Theta\partial_alpha\Phi^2=0,
\\                                                      \label{evaphi}
  \frac1{m^2}\frac{delta S}{delta\Phi}=~~~~
  &-2\partial_alpha(\partial_alpha\Phi{\sf\,sin\,}^2\Theta)=0,
\end{align}
where $\square=\partial_alpha\partial_alpha$ is the d'Alembert operator.

Let us consider a two-dimensional Minkowskian space ${\mathbb R}^{1,1}$ with
Cartesian coordinates $t,x$ and analyze static solutions. For
$\Theta=\Theta(x)$ and $\Phi=\Phi(x)$ equations of motion (\ref{evarth}),
(\ref{evaphi}) take the form
\begin{align}                                           \label{estthe}
  \Theta''-{\sf\,sin\,}\Theta{\sf\,cos\,}\Theta\Phi^{\prime 2}&=0,
\\                                                      \label{estphi}
  \left(\Phi'{\sf\,sin\,}^2\Theta\right)'&=0.
\end{align}
where prime denotes differentiation with respect to $x$. We consider
solutions of the system of ordinary differential equations in the class
of two-times differentiable functions ${\cal C}^2(L)$ on a finite interval
$x\in[0,L]$. Any solution of this system of equations belongs to one
of the following four classes. Below constants of integration are
denoted by $b,c,x_0$ and $\Phi_0$.

{\bf Degenerate solutions I.}
\begin{equation}                                        \label{efideg}
  \Theta=0,~~~~\Phi(x)\in{\cal C}(L).
\end{equation}
In this case vector $n$ is directed along $Z$ axis, and there is no rotation.

{\bf Degenerate solutions II.}
\begin{equation}                                        \label{esedeg}
  \Theta=\frac\pi2,~~~~\Phi=b(x+x_0).
\end{equation}
Here vector $n$ uniformly rotates in the $X,Y$ plane as it goes along
$x$ coordinate.

{\bf Degenerate solutions III.}
\begin{equation}                                        \label{ethdeg}
  \Theta=b(x+x_0),~~~~\Phi=\Phi_0.
\end{equation}
Here vector $n$ uniformly rotates in the $\Phi=\Phi_0$ plane as it goes
along $x$. These solutions in essence coincide with degenerate solutions II.
To show this one can use the freedom in choosing a coordinate system in the
target space and choose the new axis $Z'$ perpendicular to the plane
$\Phi=\Phi_0$. Then degenerate solutions III transform to degenerate
solutions II.

{\bf A general situation.}
In this case equation (\ref{estphi}) has a solution
\begin{equation}                                       \label{ephpti}
  \Phi'{\sf\,sin\,}^2\Theta=c,~~~~c\ne0.
\end{equation}
Then equation (\ref{estthe}) takes the form
\begin{equation*}
  \Theta''=c^2\frac{{\sf\,cos\,}\Theta}{{\sf\,sin\,}^3\Theta}.
\end{equation*}
It is easily integrated
\begin{equation}                                       \label{esolth}
  {\sf\,cos\,}\Theta=\sqrt{1-\frac{c^2}{b^2}}{\sf\,sin\,}[b(x+x_0)],~~~~|b|>|c|.
\end{equation}
After that we integrate equation (\ref{ephpti})
\begin{equation}                                        \label{esophi}
  {\sf\,tg\,}(\Phi+\Phi_0)=\frac cb{\sf\,tg\,}[b(x+x_0)].
\end{equation}
Thus formulas (\ref{esolth}), (\ref{esophi}) yield static solutions in
a general situation. Constants of integration $x_0$ and $\Phi_0$
correspond to shifts of coordinates and may be set to zero for simplicity.
Constant $b$ corresponds to choosing of a scale of $x$ coordinate.
For fixed length $L$ of the interval it can not be changed. Note that
degenerate solutions II are obtained from a general situation in the
limit $|b|=|c|$.

One can show that in a general situation vector $n$ uniformly rotates
in the plane tilted at the angle ${\sf\,arctg\,}\sqrt{c^2-1}$ to the $X,Y$
plane as it moves along $x$. This means that we have in fact only two
essentially different
solutions of the Euler--Lagrange equations. First, there are degenerate
solutions I when vector $n$ does not change in its way along $x$.
Second, all other solutions describe uniform rotation of vector $n$ in
arbitrarily fixed plane. In this case the rotational axis is always
perpendicular to vector $n$. Division of these solutions into degenerate
ones and a general situation is related to the orientation of coordinate
system with respect to the rotational plane. Note that in all cases
orientation of Cartesian coordinates axes $X,Y,Z$ in the target space
can be arbitrary with respect to space coordinate $x$.

All obtained solutions to the ${\mathbb S}^2$-model are homotopic to zero because
the fundamental group is trivial $\pi({\mathbb S}^2)=0$. It means that there is
no one-dimensional topologically nontrivial solutions in ${\mathbb S}^2$-models.

Energy of two-dimensional ${\mathbb S}^2$-model for static solutions is equal to
\begin{equation*}
  E=\int_0^L dx\left(\Theta^{\prime2}+{\sf\,sin\,}^2\Theta\Phi^{\prime2}\right).
\end{equation*}
Straightforward substitution of solutions into this integral yields the
following values
\begin{equation*}
  E=\left\lbrace
\begin{aligned}
  0, &~~~~\text{degenerate solutions I},
\\
  b^2L,&~~~~\text{all other solutions}.
\end{aligned} \right.
\end{equation*}
So the energy of static solutions is finite for finite $L$. For
$bL=2\pi m$, $m=1,2,\dotsc$ solutions are periodic. In this case they
may be considered as given on a circle.

Let us analyze the stability of the obtained solutions. The second
variation of the energy has the form
\begin{equation*}
  delta^2 E=\int_0^Ldx\left(delta\Theta^{\prime2}
  +{\sf\,cos\,}(2\Theta)\Phi^{\prime2}delta\Theta^2
  +2{\sf\,sin\,}(2\Theta)\Phi'delta\Thetadelta\Phi'
  +{\sf\,sin\,}^2\Thetadelta\Phi^{\prime2}\right).
\end{equation*}
Here variations $delta\Theta,delta\Theta',delta\Phi$ Ã¨ $delta\Phi'$ have to be
considered as independent functions. A simple analysis shows that
degenerate solutions I yield the absolute minimum, and the remaining
solutions correspond to saddle points.
%*******************************************************************
\section{Static solutions of the two-dimensional ${\mathbb S}{\mathbb O}(3)$ \\ Skyrme model}
%********************************************************************
The Euler--Lagrange equations for ${\mathbb S}{\mathbb O}(3)$ Skyrme model (\ref{elaomn})
have the form
\begin{align}                                               \nonumber
  &\frac{delta S}{delta\omega}=
\\                                                          \nonumber
  &-\varrho\square\omega+\varrho{\sf\,sin\,}\omega(\partial_alpha k\partial_alpha k)
\\                                                          \nonumber
  &-2\kappa(1-{\sf\,cos\,}\omega)\left[(\partial_{alphabeta}^2k\partial_alpha k)\partial_beta\omega
  +(\partial_alpha k\partial_alpha k)\square\omega-(\partial_alpha k\square k)\partial_alpha\omega
  -(\partial_alpha k\partial_beta k)\partial_alpha\omega\partial_beta\omega\right]
\\                                                          \nonumber
  &-\kappa{\sf\,sin\,}\omega\left[(\partial_alpha k\partial_alpha k)\partial_beta\omega^2
  -(\partial_alpha k\partial_beta k)\partial_alpha\omega\partial_beta\omega\right]
\\                                                      \label{eskome}
  &+2\kappa(1-{\sf\,cos\,}\omega){\sf\,sin\,}\omega\left[(\partial_alpha k\partial_alpha k)^2
  -(\partial_alpha k\partial_beta k)^2\right]=0,
\\                                                         \nonumber
  &\frac{delta S}{delta k_i}=
\\                                                         \nonumber
  &-2\varrho(1-{\sf\,cos\,}\omega)\square k^i
  -2\varrho{\sf\,sin\,}\omega\partial_alpha k^i\partial_alpha\omega
  -2\varrho(1-{\sf\,cos\,}\omega)(\partial_alpha k\partial_alpha k)k^i
\\                                                         \nonumber
  &-2\kappa(1-{\sf\,cos\,}\omega)\left[\square k^i\partial_alpha\omega^2
  +\partial_alpha k^i\partial_{alphabeta}^2\omega\partial_beta\omega
  -\partial_{alphabeta}^2 k^i\partial_alpha\omega\partial_beta\omega
  -\partial_alpha k^i\square\omega\partial_alpha\omega\right]
\\                                                        \nonumber
  &-4\kappa(1-{\sf\,cos\,}\omega)^2\left[(\partial_alpha k\partial_alpha k)\square k^i
  +(\partial_{alphabeta}^2k\partial_beta k)\partial_alpha k^i
  -(\square k\partial_alpha k)\partial_alpha k^i
  -(\partial_alpha k\partial_beta k)\partial_{alphabeta}^2k^i\right]
\\                                                        \nonumber
  &-8\kappa(1-{\sf\,cos\,}\omega){\sf\,sin\,}\omega\left[(\partial_beta k\partial_beta k)\partial_alpha k^i
  -(\partial_alpha k\partial_beta k)\partial_beta k^i\right]\partial_alpha\omega
\\                                                        \nonumber
  &-2\kappa(1-{\sf\,cos\,}\omega)\left[(\partial_alpha k\partial_alpha k)\partial_beta\omega^2
  -(\partial_alpha k\partial_beta k)\partial_alpha\omega\partial_beta\omega\right]k^i
\\                                                    \label{esenie}
  &-4\kappa(1-{\sf\,cos\,}\omega)^2
  \left[(\partial_alpha k\partial_alpha k)^2-(\partial_alpha k\partial_beta k)^2\right]k^i=0.
\end{align}
For variations of the action with respect to $k_i$ we used the formulae
which takes into account the constraint $(k,k)=1$,
\begin{equation*}
  \frac{delta S}{delta k_i}=\frac{\bardelta S}{\bardelta k_j}(delta^i_j-k^ik_j),
\end{equation*}
where the variation in the right hand side is taken without constraint.

One easily checks that for static solutions $\omega(x)$, $k^i(x)$ in
two-dimensional Minkowskian space-time ${\mathbb R}^{1,1}$ all terms depending
on the coupling constant $\kappa$ are cancelled. It means that for the
analysis of one-dimensional static solutions in the ${\mathbb S}{\mathbb O}(3)$-model
one may consider the Lagrangian
\begin{equation}                                        \label{elalth}
  L=\varrho\left[\frac12\partial_alpha\omega^2
  +(1-{\sf\,cos\,}\omega)\left(\partial_alpha\theta^2+{\sf\,sin\,}^2\theta\partial_alpha\varphi^2\right)\right],
\end{equation}
where we used the spherical coordinates in the target space
\begin{equation}                                        \label{epacsn}
  k^1={\sf\,sin\,}\theta{\sf\,cos\,}\varphi,~~~~k^2={\sf\,sin\,}\theta{\sf\,sin\,}\varphi,~~~~k^3={\sf\,cos\,}\theta.
\end{equation}
We use lower case Greek letters for angle coordinates of unit vector $k$
to distinguish it from vector $n$ considered in the previous section.

Equations of motion in the static case are
\begin{align}                                           \label{eqomeg}
  \frac1\varrho\frac{delta S}{delta\omega}=~~~~
  &-\omega''+{\sf\,sin\,}\omega(\theta^{\prime2}+{\sf\,sin\,}^2\theta\varphi^{\prime2})=0,
\\                                                      \label{eqthet}
  \frac1\varrho\frac{delta S}{delta\theta}=~~~~
  &-2\left((1-{\sf\,cos\,}\omega)\theta'\right)'
  +2(1-{\sf\,cos\,}\omega){\sf\,sin\,}\theta{\sf\,cos\,}\theta\varphi^{\prime2}=0,
\\                                                      \label{eqphil}
  \frac1\varrho\frac{delta S}{delta\varphi}=~~~~
  &-2\left((1-{\sf\,cos\,}\omega){\sf\,sin\,}^2\theta\varphi'\right)'=0.
\end{align}
We look for solutions of this system of differential equations in the
function space ${\cal C}^2(L)$. Any solution of the system of equations
(\ref{eqomeg})--(\ref{eqphil}) belongs to one of the following five classes.
Below constants of integration are denoted by $a,b,c,x_0,\varphi_0,\theta_0,$
and $u_0$.

{\bf Degenerate solutions I}.
In this case the rotational angle is a linear function
\begin{equation*}
  \omega=b(x+x_0),
\end{equation*}
and the rotational axis is fixed
\begin{equation*}
  \theta=\theta_0,~~\varphi=\varphi_0,~~~~\text{or}~~~~\theta=0,~~\varphi(x)\in{\cal C}^2(L).
\end{equation*}
For this solution the vector $n^i=n_0^jS_j{}^i(\omega)$ uniformly rotates
around $k$ which may have arbitrary direction as it moves along $x$. In
contrast to the ${\mathbb S}^2$-model the vector $n$ is not necessarily perpendicular
to the rotational axis.

Degenerate solutions I yield an example of static topologically nontrivial
solutions with topological charge 0 or 1. If the angle $\omega$ varies within
an interval divisible by $4\pi$ then the topological charge is zero because
the corresponding contour can be always deformed continuously to a point.
The related deformation of the contour for $0<\omega<4\pi$ is shown in
Fig.~\ref{fsohom}.
\begin{figure}[htb]%-------------------------------------------------
 \begin{center} \leavevmode \epsfysize=40mm
 \epsfbox{so3hom.eps}
 \end{center}
 \caption{The continuous deformation of the contour $0<\omega<4\pi$ to a point.
 The deformation is shown in the plane going through the vector $k$ defining
 the rotation axis. Identification of antipodal points on the boundary
 circle is shown by dashed lines.
 \label{fsohom}}
\end{figure}%---------------------------------------------------------
If the angle $\omega$ takes values in an interval containing the interval
$2\pi$ odd number of times then the topological charge equals 1.

{\bf Degenerate solutions II}.
\begin{equation}                                        \label{ethisk}
  \omega=0,~~\theta(x),\varphi(x)\in{\cal C}^2(L).
\end{equation}
Rotation does not take place for this series of solutions because the
angle of rotation equals zero.

{\bf Degenerate solutions III}.
\begin{equation*}
\begin{split}
  {\sf\,cos\,}\frac\omega2&=\sqrt{1-\frac{c^2}{4b^2}}{\sf\,sin\,}[b(x+x_0)],~~~~2|b|\ge|c|\ne0,
\\
  \theta&=\frac\pi2,
\\
  {\sf\,tg\,}(\varphi+\varphi_0)&=\frac c{2b}{\sf\,tg\,}[b(x+x_0)].
\end{split}
\end{equation*}
Polar angle $\varphi$ is a monotonic function of $x$ for these solutions,
that is the rotational axis $k^i$ rotates in the $X,Y$ plane. Here
the rotational angle changes inside the finite interval
\begin{equation*}
  2{\sf\,arccos\,}\sqrt{1-\frac{c^2}{4b^2}}<\omega
  <2\pi-2{\sf\,arccos\,}\sqrt{1-\frac{c^2}{4b^2}}.
\end{equation*}
It can be easily checked that these solutions are homotopic to zero.

{\bf Degenerate solutions IV}.
\begin{equation*}
\begin{split}
  {\sf\,cos\,}\frac\omega2&=\sqrt{1-\frac{c^2}{4b^2}}{\sf\,sin\,}[b(x+x_0)],~~~~2|b|\ge|c|\ne0,
\\
  {\sf\,tg\,}(\theta+\theta_0)&=\frac c{2b}{\sf\,tg\,}[b(x+x_0)],
\\
  \varphi&=\varphi_0.
\end{split}
\end{equation*}
These solutions coincide essentially with degenerate solutions III,
but the rotational axis rotates in the $\varphi=\varphi_0$ plane.

{\bf A general situation}.
To solve the system of equations (\ref{eqomeg})--(\ref{eqphil}) in a
general situation we introduce new coordinate
\begin{equation}                                      \label{eintux}
  u=\int^x\frac{dy}{1-{\sf\,cos\,}\omega(y)}.
\end{equation}
The coordinate $u$ increases with increasing of $x$ because
$dx/du=1-{\sf\,cos\,}\omega\ge0$. Then equations for $\theta$ and $\varphi$ (\ref{eqthet}),
(\ref{eqphil}) coincide exactly with equations for $\Theta$ and $\Phi$
(\ref{estthe}), (\ref{estphi}), in which differentiation with respect to
$x$ has to be changed to the differentiation with respect to $u$. Since
these equations were analyzed in the previous section, we are left with
solution of equation (\ref{eqomeg}) only. In a general situation it takes
the form
\begin{equation}                                        \label{eqomca}
  \omega''=c^2\frac{{\sf\,sin\,}\omega}{(1-{\sf\,cos\,}\omega)^2},~~~~c\ne0.
\end{equation}
A general solution of this equation has the form
\begin{equation}                                        \label{eqomxc}
  {\sf\,cos\,}\frac\omega2=\sqrt{1-\frac{c^2}{4b^2}}{\sf\,sin\,}[b(x+x_0)],~~~~2|b|\ge|c|.
\end{equation}
After that the integral (\ref{eintux}) can be easily taken
\begin{equation}                                        \label{ethuxc}
  {\sf\,tg\,}(cu)=\frac c{2b}{\sf\,tg\,}[b(x+x_0)],
\end{equation}
where a constant of integration is inessential.
A solution of equations (\ref{eqthet}), (\ref{eqphil}) has the form
\begin{equation*}
\begin{split}
  {\sf\,cos\,}\theta&=\sqrt{1-\frac{a^2}{c^2}}{\sf\,sin\,}[c(u+u_0)],~~~~|c|>|a|\ne0,
\\
  {\sf\,tg\,}(\varphi+\varphi_0)&=\frac ac{\sf\,tg\,}[c(u+u_0)].
\end{split}
\end{equation*}
Elementary geometrical analysis shows that solutions in a general situation
coincide in essence with degenerate solutions III and IV, but the rotational
axis rotates in the plane tilted at the angle ${\sf\,arccos\,}(a/c)$ to the $X,Y$
plane.

For static solutions the energy of two-dimensional ${\mathbb S}{\mathbb O}(3)$-model is
equal to
\begin{equation*}
  E=\int_0^L dx\left(\frac12\omega^{\prime2}+(1-{\sf\,cos\,}\omega)
  \left(\theta^{\prime2}+{\sf\,sin\,}^2\theta\varphi^{\prime2}\right)\right).
\end{equation*}
Straightforward substitution of the solutions into this integral yields
the following values
\begin{equation*}
  E=\left\lbrace
\begin{aligned}
  0, &~~~~\text{degenerate solutions II},
\\
  \frac12b^2L, &~~~~\text{degenerate solutions I},
\\
  2b^2L,&~~~~\text{all other solutions}.
\end{aligned} \right.
\end{equation*}
The energy is finite for finite $L$. Degenerate solutions II correspond
to absolute minimum because the energy is positive definite.
%*******************************************************************
\section{Projective ${\mathbb R}{\mathbb P}^d$-models}
%********************************************************************
The Lagrangian for the Skyrme model written in the form (\ref{elaomn})
can be naturally generalized to the case when the target space is
a real projective space of arbitrary dimension ${\mathbb R}{\mathbb P}^d$. Let $k^i$,
$i=1,\dotsc,d$ be a unit vector $k^2=1$ in the Euclidean space ${\mathbb R}^d$.
Consider a vector $k^i(x)$ and a scalar $\omega(x)$ fields on an arbitrary
Minkowskian space $x\in{\mathbb R}^{1,n-1}$. Obviously, the Lagrangian
\begin{equation}                                        \label{elagep}
\begin{split}
  L=A\partial_alpha\omega^2+B(\partial_alpha k\partial_alpha k)
  +C(\partial_alpha k\partial_alpha k)\partial_beta\omega^2
  +D&(\partial_alpha k\partial_beta k)\partial_alpha\omega\partial_beta\omega
\\
  +E(\partial_alpha k\partial_alpha k)^2+F&(\partial_alpha k\partial_beta k)^2+G(\partial_alpha\omega^2)^2+U,
\end{split}
\end{equation}
where $A(\omega),B(\omega),C(\omega),D(\omega),E(\omega),F(\omega),G(\omega),U(\omega)$ are
arbitrary periodic (with period $2\pi$) functions on $\omega$ is invariant
with respect to the transformations (\ref{einomn}). One can introduce
a vector field $\omega^i=\omega k^i$ all components of which are independent
as happen in the Skyrme model. Due to the equivalence relation
(\ref{eqrsog}) a vector field $\omega^i$ can be considered as taking values
inside a ball of radius $\pi$ with identified antipodal points on the
boundary sphere. It means that the field $\omega^i$ takes values in an
arbitrary projective space ${\mathbb R}{\mathbb P}^d$.

It is the most general invariant Lagrangian depending only on first
derivatives to a power not exceeding four. It is invariant with respect
to the Poicar\'e group ${\mathbb I}{\mathbb O}(1,n-1)$ acting in Minkowskian space
${\mathbb R}^{1,n-1}$, rotational group ${\mathbb O}(d)$ acting in the target space
${\mathbb R}^d$, and translations (\ref{einomn}). The rotational group ${\mathbb O}(d)$
can be extended to the group ${\mathbb O}(d+1)$ (maximal symmetry group of the
projective space ${\mathbb R}{\mathbb P}^d$) but additional transformations will act
nonlinearly on fields $\omega^i$.
%*******************************************************************
\section{Conclusion}
%********************************************************************
We considered the Skyrme model as a ${\mathbb S}{\mathbb O}(3)$-model where the target
space is the group manifold by itself using the explicit parametrization
of the ${\mathbb S}{\mathbb O}(3)$ group by elements of its algebra. Since the
fundamental group of the rotational group is nontrivial
$\pi({\mathbb S}{\mathbb O}(3))={\mathbb Z}_2$ the model admits existence of one-dimensional
topologically nontrivial solutions. Corresponding static solutions in the
two-dimensional Skyrme model are found and analyzed (degenerate
solutions I from section 7).

The form of the action for ${\mathbb S}{\mathbb U}(2)$ and ${\mathbb S}{\mathbb O}(3)$ Skyrme models
coincides because their Lie algebras are isomorphic. The difference
is in the equivalence relations in the parameter space. Hence to
construct models in mathematical physics one must specify what
manifold is a target space besides the action. This is important
because topologically nontrivial solutions of Euler--Lagrange
equations may arise. For example, in considering spinors on
three-dimensional Riemannian manifold the ${\mathbb S}{\mathbb O}(3)$-connection enters
the covariant derivative in spite of the fact that spinors transform
under the representation of unitary ${\mathbb S}{\mathbb U}(2)$ group. It is because
the ${\mathbb S}{\mathbb O}(3)$ group but not ${\mathbb S}{\mathbb U}(2)$ acts on an orthogonal vielbein
in the tangent space to a Riemannian manifold.

The ${\mathbb S}{\mathbb O}(3)$-model can be naturally generalized to a projective
space of arbitrary dimension ${\mathbb R}{\mathbb P}^d$ because the group ${\mathbb S}{\mathbb O}(3)$
as a manifold is diffeomorphic to a three-dimensional real projective
space ${\mathbb R}{\mathbb P}^3$. This allows one to define a new class of projective
models depending on eight arbitrary periodic functions of one argument.
There is a possibility of existence of one-dimensional topologically
nontrivial solutions in all these models since $\pi({\mathbb R}{\mathbb P}^d)={\mathbb Z}_2$
for $d\ge2$.

The ${\mathbb S}{\mathbb O}(3)$-model may be used in the geometric theory of defects
\cite{KatVol92,KatVol99}. The Riemann--Cartan geometry is used to
describe static distribution of dislocations and disclinations in
elastic media. The corresponding action is invariant under general
coordinate transformations and local ${\mathbb S}{\mathbb O}(3)$ rotations. Recently
the equations of elasticity theory were used to fix the coordinate
system \cite{Katana03}. This allowed to include the classical elasticity
theory in the geometric approach as a limiting case for the absence of
defects. The ${\mathbb S}{\mathbb O}(3)$-model discussed in the present paper can be used
to fix local ${\mathbb S}{\mathbb O}(3)$ rotations because it is not invariant under these
transformations. In this case the geometric theory of defects will yield
the ${\mathbb S}{\mathbb O}(3)$-model in the absence of disclinations.

The author is very grateful to I.~V.~Volovich, E.~A.~Ivanov, and
A.~I.~Pashnev for discussion of the paper and useful comments.
